title: Upgrade base image to Debian?
body:
#### Problem Description

It appears that the base image for `mitmproxy` is Debian Buster/"oldstable"; would it be possible to update, or offer, a version based on Debian Bullseye/"stable"?

#### Background

The reason I ask is that the version of GnuTLS in Debian oldstable is horribly out of date. [It includes a bug that causes it to incorrectly fail to validate TLS certificates](https://community.letsencrypt.org/t/openssl-client-compatibility-changes-for-let-s-encrypt-certificates/143816) (that link notes that GnuTLS < 3.6.14 26 is affected; [the version in Debian Buster](https://packages.debian.org/buster/libgnutls30) is 3.6.7) where the root has an expired cross-sign, [which is now the case for Let's Encrypt](https://letsencrypt.org/docs/dst-root-ca-x3-expiration-september-2021/). `apt` when talking HTTPS uses GnuTLS, so `apt-get install` against an HTTPS source (which is not normal, normally, `apt` does not use encryption when fetching packages; however, security requirements in my industry requires that we vendor packages & use TLS to prevent, e.g., supply-chain attacks; thus, we end up fetching over HTTPS) fails in Buster. We use `mitmproxy`, but also need `nc`. It used to be installed by default, back when things were based on Alpine, but that's no longer the case. We also think that the absolutely ancient version of `mitmproxy` we're using is affected by a similar bug, as it is failing to validate a cert that is actually valid, and the failures started at the time of the cross-signing cert's expiry. But we'd like to upgrade to the newer version, of course, first. But the lack of `nc` in the base image means it doesn't work as a drop in replacement, and the base image of Buster means it can't be installed.
